answer_html: and any of the last three answers would be accepted.
answer_latex: and any of the last three answers would be accepted.
hints_html:
Try to run through an algorithm every time you compute a derivative. Do you just know the derivative? If not what rules can you apply in this situation? Notice that you’re dividing two functions and that the bottom function is a composition of two functions.

The quotient rule reads if \(\displaystyle h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\) then

\(\displaystyle h'(x) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}\).

The chain rule reads if \(\displaystyle h(x) = f(g(x))\) then

\(\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\).
hints_latex:
Try to run through an algorithm every time you compute a derivative. Do
you just know the derivative? If not what rules can you apply in this
situation? Notice that you're dividing two functions and that the bottom
function is a composition of two functions.

The quotient rule reads if $\displaystyle h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$ then

$\displaystyle h'(x) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}$.

The chain rule reads if $\displaystyle h(x) = f(g(x))$ then

$\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)$.
hints_raw:
Try to run through an algorithm every time you compute a derivative. Do you just know the derivative? If not what rules can you apply in this situation? Notice that you're dividing two functions and that the bottom function is a composition of two functions.
The quotient rule reads if  <math> \displaystyle h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}</math> then

<math> \displaystyle h'(x) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}</math>.

The chain rule reads if <math> \displaystyle h(x) = f(g(x))</math> then

<math> \displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)</math>.
question: 1 (a) ii
sols_html:
This is a quotient of functions and so let \(\displaystyle f(x) = x\) and \(\displaystyle g(x) = \ln(\tfrac{1}{x})\). Then, by the quotient rule, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \frac{x}{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})} = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{g(x)^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

Now, \(\displaystyle f'(x) = 1\) and for \(\displaystyle g'(x)\), we use the chain rule to see that

\(\displaystyle g'(x) = \frac{1}{\tfrac{1}{x}}(-x^{-2}) = -\frac{1}{x}\)

Note, we could also have noticed that

\(\displaystyle g(x) = \ln(\tfrac{1}{x}) = -\ln(x)\) and hence \(\displaystyle g'(x) = -\frac{1}{x}\).

Thus, combining all this information, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \frac{x}{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})} &= \frac{(1)(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x})) - x\bigg(\frac{-1}{x}\bigg)}{(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}))^{2}} \\ &= \frac{\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}) + 1}{(\ln(\tfrac{1}{x}))^{2}} \\ &= \frac{-\ln(x) + 1}{(-\ln(x))^{2}} \\ &= \frac{1-\ln(x)}{(\ln(x))^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and any of the last three answers would be accepted.

: f(x)=\frac{x}{\ln(\frac{1}{x})}
